Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Synthesis of fluorinated block copolymers for manipulation of nanostructures using supercritical carbon dioxide

POR.DRECONTENT:
The well being of the environment has undeniably been one of the most high profile issues over the past few decades. Pressure from political and societal sources have forced many sectors to re-evaluate operations which are energy inefficient and harmful to the planet. The polymer industry has not been immune to such scrutiny. Conventional methods for polymer processing are undesirable as often, toxic solvents and high-energy methods are employed resulting in gross waste production. Consequently, tremendous amounts of research from the scientific community are in place to probe alternative, environmentally friendly technologies. One such novel route is the utilization of supercritical carbon dioxide (scCO2) as “green” solvent for polymer processes. Unlike common organic solvents, CO2 is nonflammable, readily available, and non-toxic to humans. Furthermore, mass-utilization of CO2 could solve the dilemma of how to store the green house gas sequestered during various refinement processes. Unfortunately, because of its chemically inert nature, few long-chained molecules are soluble in CO2, limiting its potential to be a vital industrial processing tool. However, a unique class of fluorinated polymers has shown inherent miscibility in CO2. In order to exploit this nature, we aimed to create a unique combination by chemically bonding a fluorinated component with a non-soluble component to produce a block copolymer.

The Takahara group (Kyushu University, Japan) has successfully synthesized fluorinated polymers, which have good miscibility in CO2, using atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP). I set forth to synthesize a block copolymer system with a fluorinated component. After discussions with Dr. Takahara, it was decided that I should attempt to synthesize poly(hexylmethacrylate_-block- poly(2-perfluoromethacrylate) (PHMA-b-PFMA-C2) for this purpose. The synthesis procedure first involved the distillation of the ligand, initiator, and monomer used to polymerize the homopolymer (PHMA) to be used as the macroinitiator. Five successful ATRP attempts of PHMA yielded over 15 grams of the polymer. This product was subsequently utilized in the ATRP of the block copolymer. In order to attain a desirable composition, I systematically varied the polymerization time and temperature to tune the ratio of the components. The final polymerization yielded approximately 3 grams of PHMA-b-PFMA-C2 with the desired composition. The product was transported back to our research lab for investigation in scCO2.

After arriving back to my home institution, I analyzed the swelling and solvation behavior of the polymer in scCO2. In doing so, we developed a better understanding of this unique mechanism. Such advances can eventually play a key role in the transformation of industrial operations to meet environmental standards. In the future, I hope to fully characterize the behavior of the material using high-resolution techniques at user facilities across the world, i.e. Spring-8 National Lab, Japan. Such collaborations will contribute to building additional relationships in Japan.
